thread.title: Australia v New Zealand Test tour: Cricket Australia XI burning questions for side featuring Shaun Marsh, Mitch Marsh, Usman Kh
thread.title_full: Australia v New Zealand Test tour: Cricket Australia XI burning questions for side featuring Shaun Marsh, Mitch Marsh, Usman Kh | The Advertiser

author: Jacob Kuriype
title: Australia v New Zealand Test tour: Cricket Australia XI burning questions for side featuring Shaun Marsh, Mitch Marsh, Usman Kh
text:
AS far as warm-ups go, it doesn’t get much harder than this.
Ahead of the first Test against Australia, New Zealand will do battle with a team featuring seven players with Test experience, in the form of a Cricket Australia XI. This is not to be confused with the current CA XI that is a team made up of promising youngsters and is taking part in the Matador Cup.
The side that will take on the Black Caps in a two-day match at Manuka Oval contains a raft of men who are likely to don the baggy green at some stage this summer.
We look at several intriguing sub plots that will play out during the tour game.
CA XI: Usman Khawaja (c), Shaun Marsh, Mitchell Marsh, Cameron Bancroft, Adam Voges, Joe Burns, Sam Whiteman, Peter Siddle, Jason Behrendorf, Billy Stanlake, Ashton Agar, Ben Taylor (12th man)
FOUR BATSMEN PLAYING FOR TWO POSITIONS
With Chris Rogers and Michael Clarke retired, there is a vacancy at the top of the order and at either first or second drop depending on where captain Steve Smith elects to bat.
So far four names have been thrown up for those two positions, with Shaun Marsh , Cameron Bancroft and Joe Burns all in contention for a spot alongside David Warner at the top of the order, and Usman Khawaja a chance of playing anywhere in the top four. Usman Khawaja and Joe Burns could be playing for the same spot in the Australia’s Test team. Source: Getty Images
All four will play for the CA XI, and pundits can look to it as a tryout to make the team for the first Test of the summer if national selector Rod Marsh’s comments are anything to go by.
“Similar to the Prime Minister’s XI squad, this two-day match will provide an opportunity for us to monitor a group of highly-rated players ahead of the first Test at the Gabba,” said national Marsh when the squad was unveiled.
Marsh appears to have the inside running, having spent the past year with the Australian Test squad and despite his struggles on the recent Ashes tour, is still viewed by many within the Aussie camp as a long-term prospect as a Test opener.
He’s also been helped by some sparkling form in the Matador Cup, where he is the leading run-scorer with 380 runs at an average of 76 for Western Australia. His Warriors teammate Bancroft isn’t too far behind, with 335 runs at 67, but Queensland duo Burns and Khawaja haven’t fared quite as well, averaging 31.60 and 38.50 respectively.
HAVE THE SELECTORS PICKED TOO STRONG A TEAM?
It’s rare for a touring side to get a chance to take on such a strong team in a warm-up match.
Last summer, when India toured Australia, its arrival coincided with the start of the Sheffield Shield season so the two tour matches it had were against a young Cricket Australia Invitational XI that was captained by Ashton Turner and did not feature a single player with a Test cap to his name.
And it’s not unusual for touring teams to face less than stellar opposition during warm-up matches.
Before the tour of Bangladesh was cancelled, Steve Smith’s men were pencilled in to take on a Bangladesh Cricket Board XI that featured no frontline spinners. And the country’s selectors made no secret of the fact that they had done so for tactical reasons. Fired up Shaun Marsh smashes 186 for the Western Warriors 0:54 Play video
Cricket: Shaun Marsh has a day to remember in the Matador Cup, slamming 186 runs on his way to becoming the highest run scorer for Western Australia in domestic one-day crickett
Fox Sports 15 Oct 2015 Sport/Cricket/Highlights “We are taking home advantage. Like any other touring side that comes to Bangladesh, we will make it challenging for Australia to play spin, which is our biggest area of strength,” selector Minhajul Abedin said.
Facing a strong team may aid New Zealand’s preparations. At the same time, with selectors still facing plenty of questions over who to bring into a side going through a generational chance, it’s understandable that they have opted to use this match as a chance to take a closer look at the candidates.
And if the CA XI has some success against the Kiwis, it could leave them with plenty of doubts in their minds heading into the Test series.
WHAT DOES THIS MEAN FOR ADAM VOGES AND MITCH MARSH
After rediscovering his form towards the end of the Ashes and being named vice-captain in place of the injured David Warner for the doomed tour of Bangladesh, Adam Voges looked a certainty to play in the Gabba Test.
So too did Mitchell Marsh after starring in Australia’s win in the final Ashes Test as well as its ODI series triumph over England in September.
Since then both have had a tough time in the Matador Cup, with Voges averaging 12.50 and Marsh 18.25 with the bat. In fairness to the latter, he has impressed with the ball, taking five wickets at an average of 25.80.
So is it a case of perform or beware for the pair? Or are selectors simply choosing to give two key players the chance to play as much red-ball cricket as possible before the first Test?
It’s worth bearing in mind the only Sheffield Shield round that takes place before the Gabba Test will be played with a pink ball. Adam Voges has had a tough Matador Cup. Source: Getty Images
WHO IS BILLY STANLAKE
Measuring up at 2.04 metres, 20-year-old Billy Stanlake is being tipped to achieve big things.
After missing the entirety of the 2014-15 season with stress fractures in his back, Stanlake debuted for Queensland in the Bulls’ first game of the season against the Tasmanian Tigers. Since then he has taken three wickets in three matches at an average of 47.00.
They aren’t the greatest numbers, but selectors saw enough in his impressive display against South Australia where he took 2-43 to give him the nod for Sunday’s game.
Stanlake has been clocked bowling speeds close to 145kph and has a big fan in Queensland teammate Chris Hartley.
“You only have to look at Billy’s stature to realise he has huge potential,” Hartley told the Courier Mail.
“When everything clicks he’s our quickest bowler and gets nice outswing on the ball.
“The ingredients are there for him to be a very dangerous fast bowler. If everything keeps heading in the direction it’s been, he’s going to play a lot of first class cricket and beyond.’’ Queensland giant Billy Stanlake is one for the future. Source: Getty Images
PETER SIDDLE STILL IN THE SELECTOR’S THOUGHTS
After proving he is still a force to be reckoned with by taking six wickets in Australia’s victory in the fifth Ashes Test in August, Peter Siddle has had to make do with carrying the drinks for Victoria in the Matador Cup.
It’s something Australia coach Darren Lehmann is not too happy about.
“I don’t know. I haven’t seen him bowl,” Lehmann said when asked about Siddle’s progress at Australia’s red-ball training camp last week. “Victoria have been nice. It has been good for them to play him, hasn’t it?
“But that’s just the way it is. We can’t control what Victoria do.
“It would be nice to see him play because we’ve got a Test match coming up. We’ll just have to wait and see.”
Lehmann will get his chance to take a closer look at Siddle over the weekend, with the 30-year-old a part of the Prime Minister’s XI for Friday’s one-dayer and the CA XI for the two-dayer starting on Sunday.
With Pat Cummins injured, James Pattinson still coming to terms with his remodelled bowling action and Josh Hazlewood only just returning to cricket after an extended rest, Siddle could be a dark horse for the third seamer’s spot alongside the left-handed Mitchells Starc and Johnson.
 Have Aussies just given the Kiwis a leg-up?
